claim: The original US constitution was written on parchment.

supporting.text: Historical records indicate that the original US Constitution was written on parchment, which was a common material for important documents in the 18th century.

attacks.text: Historical records indicate that the original US Constitution was written on parchment, which was a common material for important documents in the 18th century.
Some historians argue that early drafts of the Constitution may have been written on paper before being finalized on parchment, casting doubt on whether the 'original' was exclusively parchment.
The National Archives confirms that the final, signed version of the US Constitution is on parchment, making the distinction between drafts and the original legally irrelevant.
Parchment was not universally used for all founding documents; some state constitutions of the era were written on paper, suggesting variability in practice.
The US Constitution was intentionally given higher symbolic status than state constitutions, justifying the use of more durable parchment.

supporting.text: The National Archives, which houses the original US Constitution, confirms that the document is written on parchment.

attacks.text: The National Archives, which houses the original US Constitution, confirms that the document is written on parchment.
Some historical documents from the same era were written on vellum or other materials, leading to potential confusion about the exact material of the Constitution.
The National Archives provides detailed scientific analysis confirming the material as parchment, not vellum or other alternatives.
The term 'parchment' is sometimes used loosely to refer to any high-quality writing surface, which may not strictly mean animal-skin parchment.
Historical records and conservation reports from the National Archives specify that the Constitution is indeed on animal-skin parchment, not a substitute material.

supporting.text: Parchment was chosen for the US Constitution due to its durability and longevity, making it suitable for a foundational legal document.

attacks.text: Parchment was chosen for the US Constitution due to its durability and longevity, making it suitable for a foundational legal document.
While parchment is durable, the original US Constitution has suffered damage over time, such as fading ink and wear, undermining the claim of perfect longevity.
The damage to the original Constitution is largely due to poor preservation methods in early US history, not inherent flaws in parchment as a material.
Other materials like vellum or high-quality paper could have provided similar durability without the high cost and labor-intensive production of parchment.
Parchment was the standard for important legal documents in the 18th century, making it the most culturally and practically appropriate choice at the time.

supporting.text: Contemporary accounts from the Constitutional Convention in 1787 describe the Constitution being written on parchment, consistent with practices of the time.
